Yes actually. I find it funny that there are people who wanted it so badly that Riot did something about it to appease them. And maybe not this person, maybe not even most people, but several of the people who wanted URF to be permanent can see that it has already lost a good portion of it's luster. It is still fun in my opinion. I just got done playing it and I had a blast. It has lost a lot of it's appeal to me too however. I was actually told just last game I played that I can't play a character in the jungle because, 

*"There is no jungle in URF"*

My response to this was, 

*"There is no meta in URF"*

And there isn't, but people are beginning to adopt one, and that makes it less fun. They then continued to whine about how I lost them the game. I continued to not care, ... actually, because they were whining. It is meant to be fun. Yes, winning tends to be more fun, but the fact that I 'had to be top, or gg' doesn't make the game any fun in my opinion.

Let's be honest here, you going jungle is not necessarily fair to the one guy who has to 2v1. 

There's nothing wrong with going jungle if you explain it to others right as the game starts or play with at least a friend or two, one covering the 2v1. At least this way the "2v1 guy" can pick a heavy wave clear champion and tough it out.

But if you just pick smite, go jungle and force a guy to deal with a 2v1 he didn't ask for, you're no better than the guy who won't support in Blind pick and goes double jungle.

And there is a meta for URF, don't say otherwise. It's simply looser than the normal SR meta. The moment OP champions were found for URF that either got them perma banned by players, banned by riot themselves (and then nerfed in URF), the meta was formed.

For me and a lot of others, the mode just hasn't been fun since the first time it was out.

The reason?

On URF's first outing, Riot was **smart** to disable the most problematic champions in the mode, along with allowing players to ban 6 additional picks. This made playing a much larger variety of champions feel good and, needless to say, viable.

Since then, the same dozen or so obnoxiously broken champions have been ruling the mode because Riot fails to realize their unique URF balancing didn't do squat to make them tolerable. They will always be completely broken until they are nerfed badly enough to make them unplayable, due to the combination of utility and mechanics they have. 

This leaves players with two choices: either pick one of the few obnoxiously broken champions and join the tryharding, or have a miserable time (assuming level of skill is equal).

When a mode meant to be purely for fun becomes infested with tryhards treating it like it's ranked, it's time to move on. Sadly, all the "fun" modes have been devolving just the same.
I agree on so many levels. Riot needs to individually balance champions on URF, because it got extremely obnoxious, extremely quick.

I actually completely agree with him. URF got stale incredibly fast, now that we only see the same 10-15 champions. If you actually want to have **fun** by picking a different champion, you'll just get instantly destroyed by an urgot or a zed. Disabling certain champs doesn't really fix the problem though, then people will just pick the *next* 10-15 broken champions in the line. What would actually fix the problem is them individually balancing champions for URF. Slightly increasing cooldowns for urgot so he can't shoot 213 times a second, things like that. It will never happen though, because it would take Riot actually caring. Also it would take work, and we know that's not happening.
